title: SurvBregDiv: Bregman Divergence Data Integration for Time-to-Event Modelling
text: Accurate prognostic modeling central goal survival analysis. rapid expansion large-scale biobank initiatives‚Äîrich genetic, molecular, imaging, electronic health record data‚Äîcreated new opportunities improve predictive performance clinical epidemiologic research. However, datasets often exhibit limited effective sample sizes, high dimensionality, low signal--noise ratios, additional practical constraints including privacy considerations restricted data access. Integrating external information offers principled strategy improving model efficiency. Yet, classical data-integration methods typically rely assumption multiple datasets arise common data-generating mechanism. modern biomedical applications, assumption rarely satisfied. Misspecification due population heterogeneity can induce substantial bias, motivating development transfer-learning approaches explicitly accommodate -source discrepancies. Bregman divergence successfully applied borrowing information binary-outcome settings, extending ideas censored time--event outcomes nontrivial due right censoring limited nature available external survival information (e.g., predicted risk scores, fitted regression coefficients, hazard ratios without access baseline hazard). Beyond full-cohort survival studies, many biomedical investigations rely nested case‚Äìcontrol (NCC) design alleviate burden labor-intensive measurements, high-cost data acquisition, destructive finite biospecimen assays. NCC design, small number matched controls sampled failure time, producing survival data analyzed conditional logistic regression applied matched risk sets. Despite practical relevance, existing methodology software supports transfer learning external information borrowing NCC designs. SurvBregDiv package addresses challenges providing unified Bregman Divergence transfer-learning framework full-cohort Cox data nested case‚Äìcontrol designs. methods integrate external information privacy-preserving manner applicable low-dimensional settings high-dimensional variable selection ridge, lasso, elastic net penalties.

code: data(ExampleData_lowdim)  train  <- ExampleData_lowdim$train test   <- ExampleData_lowdim$test  z      <- train$z delta  <- train$status time   <- train$time strat  <- train$stratum beta_ext <- ExampleData_lowdim$beta_external_fair eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 10)  fit.coxkl <- coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list ) RS_ext <- as.matrix(z) %*% as.matrix(beta_ext)  fit.coxkl.RS <- coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   RS = RS_ext,   etas = eta_list ) cvfit.coxkl <- cv.coxkl(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list,   nfolds = 5,   criteria = "V&VH",   seed = 1) cv.plot(cvfit.coxkl) time_ties <- round(time, 2)   # Rounding time introduces ties for demonstration  fit.coxkl.ties <- coxkl_ties(   z = z,   delta = delta,   time = time_ties,   stratum = strat,   beta = beta_ext,   etas = eta_list,   ties = "breslow" )

code: data(ExampleData_highdim)  train_hd  <- ExampleData_highdim$train test_hd   <- ExampleData_highdim$test  z_hd      <- train_hd$z delta_hd  <- train_hd$status time_hd   <- train_hd$time strat_hd  <- train_hd$stratum  beta_external_hd <- ExampleData_highdim$beta_external fit.coxkl_ridge <- coxkl_ridge(   z        = z_hd,   delta    = delta_hd,   time     = time_hd,   stratum  = strat_hd,   beta     = beta_external_hd,   eta      = 1                  ) fit.coxkl_LASSO <- coxkl_enet(   z        = z_hd,   delta    = delta_hd,   time     = time_hd,   stratum  = strat_hd,   beta     = beta_external_hd,      eta      = 1,                    alpha    = 1                  # LASSO penalty ) plot(   fit.coxkl_LASSO,   test_z       = test_hd$z,   test_time    = test_hd$time,   test_delta   = test_hd$status,   test_stratum = test_hd$stratum,   criteria     = "loss" ) eta_grid_hd <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 100)  cvfit.coxkl_LASSO <- cv.coxkl_enet(   z = z_hd,   delta = delta_hd,   time = time_hd,   stratum = strat_hd,   beta = beta_external_hd,   etas = eta_grid_hd,   alpha = 1, # LASSO   nfolds = 5,   cv.criteria = "V&VH",   seed = 1 ) head(cvfit.coxkl_LASSO$integrated_stat.best_per_eta) ##          eta     lambda     Loss ## 1 0.00000000 0.10193604 2.842157 ## 2 0.09953651 0.09773006 2.840152 ## 3 0.20888146 0.09390799 2.838419 ## 4 0.32900138 0.02575599 2.829181 ## 5 0.46095806 0.02161908 2.817568 ## 6 0.60591790 0.01818471 2.806310 cv.plot(cvfit.coxkl_LASSO)

text: built-simulated dataset NCC designs, ExampleData_cc, contains training set (1000 samples) test set (2500 samples). data include stratum variable, observations stratum ID belong matched set. training data contain 200 matched sets test data contain 500 matched sets, constructed 1:4 matching scheme. dataset includes six predictors (Z1‚ÄìZ6). Users must specify tie-handling method via method argument. 1:M matched case‚Äìcontrol studies, "breslow" "exact" yield identical results, although "exact" theoretically preferable. n:m matched designs n>1n > 1, two methods can differ. use KL divergence‚Äìbased integrated model, user must least provide estimated external regression coefficients ùõÉÃÉ\widetilde{\boldsymbol{\beta}} via argument beta function clogitkl(). integration weights Œ∑\eta can generated using function generate_eta(). user rely prior knowledge problem-specific considerations determine appropriate range Œ∑\eta values. Users may directly call plot() method visualize model‚Äôs fitted performance training data without providing additional test data. test set supplied, performance metrics computed using test set instead:  Cross-validation tuning Œ∑\eta can performed via cv.clogitkl(), performs K-fold cross-validation tune integration parameter Œ∑\eta. supported criteria include predicted deviance (loss), AUC (Hanley McNeil 1982), Brier Score (Brier)(Glenn et al. 1950). details, please refer Page: Appendix: CV Criteria. demonstrate tuning Œ∑\eta using 5-fold cross-validation V&VH criterion LASSO-penalized integrated model (alpha = 1). range integration weights Œ∑\eta can generated using function generate_eta(). user rely prior knowledge problem-specific considerations determine appropriate range. (ridge, use cv.coxkl_ridge() analogously.) cross-validated performance curve can visualized using cv.plot():  plot displays purple curve tracing cross-validated performance across Œ∑\eta grid, green dotted horizontal line representing internal baseline etaeta = 0 (green point marking value), vertical dashed orange line indicating optimal Œ∑\eta cross-validated loss minimized.
code: data(ExampleData_cc)  train.cc  <- ExampleData_cc$train test.cc   <- ExampleData_cc$test  z.cc      <- train.cc$z y.cc      <- train.cc$y set.cc    <- train.cc$stratum  beta_ext.cc <- ExampleData_cc$beta_external eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 5)  clogitkl.fit_breslow <- clogitkl(y = y.cc, z = z.cc, stratum = set.cc,                                   eta = eta_list, beta = beta_ext.cc,                                  method = "breslow") plot(   clogitkl.fit_breslow,   test_z       = test.cc$z,   test_delta   = test.cc$y,   test_stratum = test.cc$stratum,   criteria     = "loss" ) cv.clogitkl.fit_breslow <- cv.clogitkl(   y        = y.cc,   z        = z.cc,   stratum  = set.cc,   beta     = beta_ext.cc,   etas     = eta_list,   method   = "exact",   nfolds   = 5,   criteria = "loss" ) cv.plot(cv.clogitkl.fit_breslow)

title: SurvBregDiv: Bregman Divergence Data Integration for Time-to-Event Modelling
text: built-simulated dataset NCC designs, ExampleData_cc_highdim, contains training set 50 matched sets test set 500 matched sets, constructed 1:5 matching scheme. dataset includes 10 predictors (Z1‚ÄìZ20). Externally derived coefficients provided beta_external: high-dimensional NCC data, demonstrate usage clogitkl_enet(), fits KL-integrated conditional logistic regression models elastic-net penalties. fitted object can visualized using S3 plot() method:  Cross-validation tuning Œ∑\eta can performed via cv.clogitkl_enet(): cross-validated performance curve can visualized using cv.plot():  plot displays purple curve tracing cross-validated performance across Œ∑\eta grid, green dotted horizontal line representing internal baseline eta = 0 (green point marking value), vertical dashed orange line indicating optimal Œ∑\eta cross-validated loss minimized.
code: data(ExampleData_cc_highdim)  train.cc_hd  <- ExampleData_cc_highdim$train test.cc_hd   <- ExampleData_cc_highdim$test  z.cc_hd      <- train.cc_hd$z y.cc_hd      <- train.cc_hd$y set.cc_hd    <- train.cc_hd$stratum  beta_ext.cc_hd <- ExampleData_cc_highdim$beta_external clogitkl_enet_fit <- clogitkl_enet(   y       = y.cc_hd,   z       = z.cc_hd,   stratum = set.cc_hd,   beta    = beta_ext.cc_hd,   eta     = 0 ) plot(   clogitkl_enet_fit,   test_z       = test.cc_hd$z,   test_delta   = test.cc_hd$y,   test_stratum = test.cc_hd$stratum,   criteria     = "loss" ) eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 5) cv.clogitkl_enet_fit <- cv.clogitkl_enet(   y        = y.cc_hd,   z        = z.cc_hd,   stratum  = set.cc_hd,   beta     = beta_ext.cc_hd,   etas     = eta_list,   alpha    = 1,   nfolds   = 5,   criteria = "loss" ) cv.plot(cv.clogitkl_enet_fit)

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) ‚Äî clogitkl
text: function maps Conditional Logistic Regression problem Cox Proportional Hazards model fixed event time \(T=1\) event indicator \(\delta=y\). utilizes coxkl_ties core engine perform data integration via KL divergence penalty. Method: method ("breslow" "exact") specifies form partial likelihood used. 1:M matched case-control studies, "breslow" "exact" yield identical results, "exact" theoretically preferable. \(n:m\) matched designs (\(n>1\)), results differ. External Information: Larger values tuning parameter eta enforce stronger agreement external coefficients beta. Standard CLR: Setting etas = 0 (including 0 sequence) recovers standard Maximum Likelihood Estimates Conditional Logistic Regression.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence (CLR-KL) ‚Äî clogitkl
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Load the matched case-control example data data(ExampleData_cc) train_cc <- ExampleData_cc$train  y <- train_cc$y z <- train_cc$z sets <- train_cc$stratum  eta_list <- generate_eta(method = "exponential", n = 50, max_eta = 50) external_beta <- ExampleData_cc$beta_external  # Fit CLR-KL using the Breslow approximation clogitkl.fit_breslow <- clogitkl(y = y, z = z, stratum = sets,                                   eta = eta_list, beta = external_beta,                                  method = "breslow") } # }

what: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
text: Fits Conditional Logistic Regression model matched case-control (1:M) data mapping problem Cox proportional hazards model fixed event time, integrating external information via Kullback‚ÄìLeibler (KL) divergence applying Elastic Net (Lasso + Ridge) penalty variable selection regularization. function thin wrapper around coxkl_enet: maps CLR problem Cox model \(T = 1\) \(\delta = y\) calls coxkl_enet core engine. External information can provided either : RS: Precomputed external risk scores (aligned rows z). beta: Externally derived coefficients (converted risk scores internally). strength integration controlled tuning parameter eta, alpha lambda govern Elastic Net penalty.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
code: clogitkl_enet(   y,   z,   stratum,   RS = NULL,   beta = NULL,   eta = NULL,   alpha = NULL,   lambda = NULL,   nlambda = 100,   lambda.min.ratio = 0.001,   lambda.early.stop = FALSE,   tol = 1e-04,   Mstop = 1000,   max.total.iter = (Mstop * nlambda),   group = 1:ncol(z),   group.multiplier = NULL,   standardize = TRUE,   nvar.max = ncol(z),   group.max = length(unique(group)),   stop.loss.ratio = 0.01,   actSet = TRUE,   actIter = Mstop,   actGroupNum = sum(unique(group) != 0),   actSetRemove = FALSE,   returnX = FALSE,   trace.lambda = FALSE,   message = FALSE,   ... )

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
text: y Numeric vector binary outcomes (0 = control, 1 = case). z Numeric matrix covariates (predictors). Rows observations, columns variables. stratum Numeric factor vector defining matched sets (strata). required conditional logistic regression. RS Optional numeric vector external risk scores. Length must equal nrow(z). provided, beta must supplied. beta Optional numeric vector external coefficients. Length must equal ncol(z). provided, used calculate risk scores. provided, RS must supplied. eta Numeric scalar. tuning parameter KL divergence (integration strength). Defaults 0 (external information). alpha Elastic Net mixing parameter, \(0 < \alpha \le 1\). alpha = 1 Lasso penalty, alpha close 0 approaches Ridge. NULL, set 1 warning inside coxkl_enet. lambda Optional numeric vector penalty parameters. NULL, path generated automatically. nlambda Integer. Number lambda values generate lambda NULL. Default 100. lambda.min.ratio Numeric. Ratio smallest largest lambda sequence lambda NULL. Default 1e-3. Users may override mimic behavior coxkl_enet. lambda.early.stop Logical. TRUE, stops lambda path early loss improvement small. tol Numeric. Convergence tolerance optimization. Default 1e-4. Mstop Integer. Maximum iterations inner loop per lambda. Default 1000. max.total.iter Integer. Maximum total iterations across entire lambda path. Default Mstop * nlambda. group Integer vector defining group membership grouped penalties. Default treats variable group (1:ncol(z)). group.multiplier Numeric vector. Multiplicative factors penalties applied group. standardize Logical. TRUE, z standardized internally. Coefficients returned original scale. Default TRUE. nvar.max Integer. Maximum number active variables allowed. Default ncol(z). group.max Integer. Maximum number active groups allowed. Default total number unique groups. stop.loss.ratio Numeric. Threshold early stopping based loss ratio. Default 1e-2. actSet Logical. TRUE, uses active-set strategy optimization. Default TRUE. actIter Integer. Iterations active set refinement. Default Mstop. actGroupNum Integer. Limit active groups active-set strategy. Default sum(unique(group) != 0). actSetRemove Logical. Whether allow removal groups active set. Default FALSE. returnX Logical. TRUE, returns standardized design matrix processed data result. Default FALSE. trace.lambda Logical. TRUE, prints lambda sequence progress. Default FALSE. message Logical. TRUE, prints informative messages fitting. Default FALSE. ... Additional arguments passed coxkl_enet.

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
text: object class "clogitkl_enet" "coxkl_enet" containing: beta Matrix coefficient estimates (p x nlambda). lambda Sequence lambda values used. alpha Elastic Net mixing parameter used. likelihood Vector negative log-partial likelihoods (loss) lambda. df Vector degrees freedom (number non-zero coefficients) lambda. iter Vector iteration counts lambda. W Matrix exponentiated linear predictors (risk scores) original scale. data List containing input data used (including y, z, stratum, external information).

title: Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Divergence and Elastic Net Penalty (CLR-KL-ENet) ‚Äî clogitkl_enet
text: function assumes 1:M matched case-control design, stratum corresponds matched set containing one case (y = 1) one controls (y = 0). CLR likelihood equivalent Cox partial likelihood common event time within matched set. Thus, define \(\delta_i = y_i\) \(T_i = 1\) subjects fit stratified Cox model KL divergence Elastic Net penalty via coxkl_enet. eta = 0, method reduces standard Elastic Net CLR (ignoring external information). alpha = 1, penalty Lasso. alpha close 0, penalty approaches Ridge.

title: Cox Proportional Hazards Model with KL Divergence for Data Integration (Ties Handling) ‚Äî coxkl_ties
text: objective function weighted combination internal partial likelihood KL divergence external information derived beta. KL Divergence Weighting: Larger values eta place weight matching risk set behavior implied external coefficients. Standard Cox: eta = 0 corresponds standard Cox model, relying solely internal partial likelihood. Ties Handling: calculation partial likelihood uses method specified ties argument ("breslow" "exact"). exact method may computationally intensive datasets many tied events. function uses "warm start" strategy solution current eta used initial value next eta sorted sequence.

Fit the model using Breslow's approximation for ties (Default) coxkl_ties.fit_Breslow <- coxkl_ties(     z = train_dat_lowdim$z,     delta = train_dat_lowdim$status,     time = train_dat_lowdim$time,     stratum = train_dat_lowdim$stratum,     beta = ExampleData_lowdim$beta_external_fair,     etas = eta_list,     ties = "breslow" )  # 2. Fit the model using the Exact method for ties coxkl_ties.fit_Exact <- coxkl_ties(     z = train_dat_lowdim$z,     delta = train_dat_lowdim$status,     time = train_dat_lowdim$time,     stratum = train_dat_lowdim$stratum,     beta = ExampleData_lowdim$beta_external_fair,     etas = eta_list,     ties = "exact" ) } # }

text: fitted objective $$\ell_\eta(\beta) = \ell_{\text{int}}(\beta) + \eta \, \ell_{\text{ext}}(\beta),$$ equivalent fitting stratified Cox model stacked data observation weights 1 (internal) eta (external), keeping internal external strata separated (mixing risk sets across cohorts). function fits one model per eta value. uses warm-start strategy: solution current eta used initial value next eta sorted sequence.

"AUC": Matched-set AUC based within-stratum comparisons (higher better). "CIndex": Concordance index matched-set setting, implemented via matched-set AUC calculation "AUC" (higher better). "Brier": Conditional Brier score using within-stratum softmax probabilities (lower better). Default "loss". message Logical; TRUE, prints progress messages fold-wise evaluation progress bars. title: Cross-Validated Conditional Logistic Regression with KL Integration ‚Äî cv.clogitkl
text: matched case‚Äìcontrol problem handled via clogitkl, maps Conditional Logistic Regression Cox model fixed event time uses coxkl_ties core engine. Cross-validation performed stratum level: matched set treated indivisible unit assigned single fold using get_fold_cc. ensures conditional likelihood well-defined within training test split. criteria argument controls CV performance metric: "loss": Average negative conditional log-likelihood held-strata. fold, conditional log-likelihood computed test matched sets using fitted \(\hat\beta\) corresponding training data; fold-wise losses averaged. "AUC": matched-set AUC based within-stratum comparisons. stratum, case score compared control scores, counting concordant/discordant/tied pairs aggregating across strata. Higher AUC indicates better discrimination. "CIndex": Alias "AUC". 1:m matched case‚Äìcontrol setting, matched-set AUC equivalent conditional concordance index, computed using path "AUC". "Brier": conditional Brier score based within-stratum softmax probabilities. stratum, probability assigned member via \(\hat p_{si} = \exp(\eta_{si}) / \sum_{j \S_s} \exp(\eta_{sj})\), Brier score mean squared error \((Y_{si} - \hat p_{si})^2\) across observations. Lower Brier indicates better conditional calibration sharpness. returned object structure "cv.coxkl" objects cv.coxkl_ties, facilitating downstream code reuse.

text: simulated dataset generated 1:M matched case-control studies (Conditional Logistic Regression, CLR). data organized matched sets (strata), exactly one case (y=1) \(m=4\) controls (y=0) per set.

title: Example Data for Conditional Logistic Regression ‚Äî ExampleData_cc
code: data(ExampleData_cc)

title: Example Data for Conditional Logistic Regression ‚Äî ExampleData_cc
text: list containing following elements: train list components training CLR model: z Numeric matrix covariates (dimension \(n_{\mathrm{train}}\times 6\)) columns named Z1‚ÄìZ6. y Binary outcome vector (1=case, 0=control). stratum Integer vector identifying matched set observation (200 unique strata train). test list structure train, used external evaluation (500 unique strata test). beta_external Numeric vector (length 6) CLR coefficients estimated separate external dataset using Z1‚ÄìZ6.

title: Example Data for Conditional Logistic Regression ‚Äî ExampleData_cc
text: Data-generating mechanism: Study design: 1:4 matched case-control study (\(m=4\) controls per case). Covariates: 6 variables (Z1‚ÄìZ6) drawn correlated multivariate normal distribution. True coefficients: \(\beta = (1, -1, 1, -1, 1, -1)\). Set-specific effect: random stratum-specific intercept \(\theta_i \sim N(0, 0.5^2)\) added linear predictor; eliminated CLR conditioning. Outcome generation: Within stratum \(\), single case (y=1) selected probability proportional \(\exp(\theta_i + Z^\top \beta)\). External beta estimation: beta_external obtained fitting clogit separate simulated dataset slightly different true coefficient vector \(\beta_{\mathrm{ext}} = (0.8, -0.8, \dots)\) correlation \(\rho = 0.3\), using "breslow" tie approximation.

title: Example high-dimensional survival data ‚Äî ExampleData_highdim
text: list following components: train list containing: z data frame dimension \(n_{\mathrm{train}} \times 50\) containing covariates Z1‚ÄìZ50. status numeric vector event indicators (1=event, 0=censored). time numeric vector observed survival times \(\min(T, C)\). stratum vector stratum labels (equal 1). test list structure train, covariates dimension \(n_{\mathrm{test}} \times 50\). beta_external numeric vector length 50 (named Z1‚ÄìZ50) containing Cox regression coefficients estimated external dataset using Z1‚ÄìZ6, zeros Z7‚ÄìZ50. beta_external.multi1 External coefficient vector additive Gaussian noise applied nonzero entries beta_external, preserving original sparsity pattern. beta_external.multi2 External coefficient vector weak Gaussian noise applied 50 coefficients, yielding dense low-magnitude perturbation. beta_external.multi3 scaled version beta_external uniformly attenuated signal strength. beta_external.multi4 External coefficient vector subset nonzero coefficients beta_external signs randomly flipped. beta_external.multi5 External coefficient vector weakened original signals small number newly introduced weak signals among previously zero coefficients.

title: Example high-dimensional survival data ‚Äî ExampleData_highdim
text:
Data-generating mechanism: Covariates: 50 covariates true signals Z1‚ÄìZ6 noise variables Z7‚ÄìZ50. Z1, Z2: bivariate normal AR(1) correlation \(ho = 0.5\). Z3, Z4: independent Bernoulli(0.5). Z5 \(\sim N(2, 1)\), Z6 \(\sim N(-2, 1)\). Z7‚ÄìZ50: multivariate normal AR(1) correlation \(ho = 0.5\). True coefficients: \( eta = (0.3, -0.3, 0.3, -0.3, 0.3, -0.3, 0, \ldots, 0)\). Event times: Weibull baseline hazard \(h_0(t) = \lambda 
u t^{
u - 1}\) \(\lambda = 1\) \(
u = 2\). Given linear predictor \(\eta = Z^	op  eta\), event times generated $$T = \left( rac{-\log U}{\lambda e^{\eta}}ight)^{1/
u},     \quad U \sim \mathrm{Unif}(0,1).$$ Censoring: \(C \sim \mathrm{Unif}(0, \mathrm{ub})\), ub tuned achieve target censoring rate (internal: 0.70; external: 0.50). observed time \(\min(T, C)\) event indicator \(\mathbf{1}\{T \le C\}\). External coefficients: Cox regression models Breslow ties fitted external dataset using Z1‚ÄìZ6. resulting estimates embedded length-50 coefficient vectors, additional variants constructed represent different forms coefficient perturbation distributional shift.

what: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties ‚Äî sim.cox.highdim
title: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties ‚Äî sim.cox.highdim
text: Internal function generate time--event data stratified Cox proportional hazards model high-dimensional covariates, stratum-specific multiplicative baseline scaling, controllable random censoring. Event times generated inverse transform sampling using baseline cumulative hazard. model $$h(t \mid Z, s) = \gamma_s \, h_0(t)\, \exp(Z^\top \beta),$$ \(\gamma_s\) stratum-specific positive constant, \(h_0(t)\) baseline hazard, \(\beta\) coefficient vector. Supported baseline hazards: "exponential": \(h_0(t)=1\), \(H_0(t)=t\). "weibull": \(h_0(t)=\alpha t\) \(\alpha>0\), \(H_0(t)=\alpha t^2/2\). Censoring implemented $$T_{\mathrm{obs}} = \min(T, C, \texttt{max_time}),$$ \(C\) random censoring time drawn specified distribution calibrated approximately match target censoring rate. Supported random censoring distributions: "uniform": \(C \sim \mathrm{Unif}(0, c_{\max})\). "exponential": \(C \sim \mathrm{Exp}(\lambda_c)\). "weibull": \(C \sim \mathrm{Weibull}(k, \lambda_c)\), shape \(k\) specified censor_weibull_shape. "lognormal": \(C \sim \mathrm{LogNormal}(\mu_c, \sigma_c^2)\), \(\sigma_c\) specified censor_lognormal_sdlog. "none": random censoring; administrative censoring via max_time. Binary covariates can specified index via binary_idx. variables generated using latent Gaussian threshold model achieve desired prevalence approximate within-binary correlation controlled rho_binary. Specifically, \(B\) binary \(P(B=1)=p\), generated \(B = (L > c)\) \(L\) standard normal \(c=\Phi^{-1}(1-p)\). multiple binary covariates requested, latent variables generated jointly equicorrelation rho_binary. controls latent (tetrachoric) correlation; resulting Pearson correlation among binary variables constrained prevalence generally close identical rho_binary. ties=TRUE, observed times discretized ties_levels bins (based sample quantiles) replaced bin midpoints induce tied event/censoring times. Smaller ties_levels produces stronger ties.

title: Simulate stratified Cox PH survival data with flexible censoring, optional binary covariates, and optional ties ‚Äî sim.cox.highdim
text: n_stratum Integer. Number strata. n.beta Integer. Total number covariates \(p\). beta_value_vec Numeric vector. True coefficients first length(beta_value_vec) covariates. Remaining coefficients (n.beta) set 0. beta_idx Integer vector NULL. Indices (1:n.beta) covariates nonzero true coefficients. NULL, defaults 1:length(beta_value_vec) (original behavior). Must length beta_value_vec filtering valid indices. mu_Z Numeric vector NULL. Mean vector continuous covariates. NULL, zero vector used. indices binary_idx, mu_Z ignored. stratum_size Integer numeric vector. Stratum sample sizes. scalar, recycled length n_stratum; vector, must length n_stratum. rho Numeric. Correlation parameter \([0,1)\) equicorrelation covariance structure used generate continuous covariates. censor_rate Numeric. Target random censoring rate \([0,1)\). 0, random censoring applied (administrative censoring via max_time may still apply). censor_type Character. Random censoring distribution. One "uniform", "exponential", "weibull", "lognormal", "none". max_time Numeric. Administrative censoring time. Observed time min(event, censor, max_time). seed Integer NULL. Random seed reproducibility. baseline Character. Baseline hazard type. One "exponential" "weibull". alpha Numeric NULL. Required baseline="weibull". Controls Weibull baseline hazard \(h_0(t)=\alpha t\); must positive finite. Ignored baseline="exponential". censor_weibull_shape Numeric. Shape parameter \(k>0\) Weibull random censoring censor_type="weibull". scale parameter calibrated internally match censor_rate. Ignored otherwise. censor_lognormal_sdlog Numeric. Log-scale standard deviation \(\sigma_c>0\) log-normal random censoring censor_type="lognormal". mean log scale calibrated internally match censor_rate. Ignored otherwise. binary_idx Integer vector. Indices (1:n.beta) covariates generated binary. Default none (covariates continuous). binary_prev Numeric scalar vector. Prevalence \(P(Z_j=1)\) binary covariates. scalar, recycled binary covariates. Must \((0,1)\). rho_binary Numeric. Equicorrelation parameter \([0,1)\) latent Gaussian vector used generate binary covariates. Ignored binary_idx empty. ties Logical. TRUE, discretize observed times induce ties. ties_levels Integer. Number bins used discretize time ties=TRUE. Smaller values yield stronger ties. Must \(\ge 2\).
